hint.text: Non-terminating decimals can be identified without actually performing the long division

solution.text:
As per the theorem that says if x=\(\frac pq\) be a rational number, such that the prime factorization of q is not of the form \(2^n\times 5^m\).
Then, x has a decimal expansion which is non-terminating repeating.
So, we just need to check for the denominator(q) of the given fraction
if q is a factor of any prime number other 2 or 5 then it is non terminating
So we solve and get,\(\frac {_{l}_}{_{{pow(7,j)}}_}=\frac {_{l}_}{7^_{j}_}\)
similarly, \(\frac {_{l}_}{_{{pow(3,j)}}_}=\frac {_{l}_}{ 3^_{j}_}\)
\(\frac {_{l}_}{_{{pow(11,j)}}_}=\frac {_{l}_}{11^_{j}_}\)
But in one of the option ,\(\frac {_{l}_}{_{{pow(5,j)*pow(2,j)}}_}=\frac {_{l}_}{2^_{j}_\times 5^_{j}_}\)
\(\Rightarrow \) this fraction is a terminating decimal

content.text: From the fractions given below choose the ones which when converted in the decimal form will result in a non terminating and repeating decimal
